items.title: problem on working with Jupyter Notebook
items.body:
When working on Jupyter Nootebook with the below code

```
import chainer.links as L
from chainer import Variable, cuda
import cupy
import multiprocessing
from multiprocessing import Process
from worker import exe_fn  
lis=multiprocessing.Manager().list()
def f(x, model):
    lis.append(model(x).data)
if __name__ == '__main__':
    multiprocessing.set_start_method('forkserver')
    x1_data = cupy.ones((1,5), cupy.float32)
    #x2_data = cupy.ones((1,5), cupy.float32)
    x1 = Variable(cuda.to_gpu(x1_data, 0))
    #x2 = Variable(cuda.to_gpu(x2_data, 0))
    model = L.Linear(5,2)
    model1 = model.copy().to_gpu(0)
    #model2 = model.copy().to_gpu(0)
    #p1 = Process(target=f, args=(x1,model1,))
    #p2 = Process(target=f, args=(x2,model2,))
    p1 = Process(target=exe_fn, args=(f,(x1,model1)))
    #p2 = Process(target=exe_fn, args=(f,(x2,model1)))
    p1.start()
    #p2.start()
    p1.join()
    #p2.join()
```

I got error like



```
RuntimeErrorTraceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-1-bc0a324c25a0> in <module>
     15 
     16 if __name__ == '__main__':
---> 17     multiprocessing.set_start_method('forkserver')
     18     #multiprocessing.set_start_method('spawn')
     19     x1_data = cupy.ones((1,5), cupy.float32)

/usr/lib/python3.6/multiprocessing/context.py in set_start_method(self, method, force)
    240     def set_start_method(self, method, force=False):
    241         if self._actual_context is not None and not force:
--> 242             raise RuntimeError('context has already been set')
    243         if method is None and force:
    244             self._actual_context = None

RuntimeError: context has already been set
```

My plan was to use atleast one cupy enabled process and make them use shared variable so that I can cooperate with non-GPU initiative process afterwards.
I have only one GPU to work with
Please help me out on this

items.title: Unable to run mnist dual parallel example

labels.name: cat:bug
labels.description: Bug report or fix.

labels.name: prio:high
labels.description: High priority. Urgent and needs to be worked on as soon as possible.

items.body:
Python version: 3.7
OS/Platform: Red Hat 7.6

I am unable to run the chainermn dual parallel example (chainer/examples/chainermn/mnist/train_mnist_dual_parallel.py) with chainer version `7.1.0`. I was able to run this example previously with chainer version `6.2.0`.

The error I get is

```
  File "chainer/chainermn/mnist/train_mnist_dual_parallel.py", line 156, in <module>
    main()
  File "chainer/chainermn/mnist/train_mnist_dual_parallel.py", line 152, in main
    trainer.run()
  File "/opt/chainer/chainer/training/trainer.py", line 376, in run
    six.reraise(*exc_info)
  File "/opt/chainer/six.py", line 703, in reraise
    raise value
  File "/opt/chainer/chainer/training/trainer.py", line 346, in run
    entry.extension(self)
  File "/opt/chainer/chainer/training/extensions/evaluator.py", line 180, in __call__
    result = self.evaluate()
  File "/opt/chainer/chainermn/extensions/multi_node_evaluator.py", line 229, in new_evaluate
    array0 = list(local_mean_dict.values())[0]
IndexError: list index out of range
```

I noticed that since release 6.2.0 some modification has been made to multi_node_evaluator.py, specifically the addition of the following lines
```
        # ChainerX support:
        # We need convert chainerx ndarray to Native array because
        #   (1) allreduce_obj is used to compute global mean values, since
        #       a simple allreduce operation cannot be applied in evaluation.
        #   (2) allreduce_obj calls mpi4py.allreduce, which pickles the object
        #   (3) chainerx.ndarray preserves CUDA device internally when pickled
        #   (4) An error will occur when an ndarray is unpickled in another
        #       process
        array0 = list(local_mean_dict.values())[0]
        xp = backend.get_array_module(array0)
        if xp == chx and array0.device.backend.name == 'cuda':
            # Results of evaluation is fairly small, so
            # the ndarray is transferred to CPU and allreduce()-ed.
            # NOTE: Matrices for evaluation are transferred to the host memory
            # and sent via MPI instead of NCCL. Although evaluation matrices
            # are small in most cases, this is a potential performance issue.
            local_mean_dict = {
                name: chx.to_numpy(value)
                for name, value in local_mean_dict.items()
            }
```
I have also installed ChainerX  but I still get the same error. The Data Parallel (`train_mnist.py`) and Model Parallel (`train_mnist_model_parallel.py`) examples are able to run successfully.

items.title: Get Weight
items.body:
Hello, I'm looking through the documentation to find a way to get weight of neurons.

I build a Sequential network, for example 
`model = chainer.Sequential()
bias = False
layer = chainer.links.Linear(5, 10, nobias=bias)
model.append(layer)`

If I Use print(model)
it return : 
Sequential(
  (0): Linear(in_size=5, out_size=10, nobias=False),
)

but i'm not able to find a way to get the wieght of this layer.

Do you know a solution?

Thank you, have a nice day

items.title: `optimizer.use_fp32_update` on ChainerX model

labels.name: cat:bug
labels.description: Bug report or fix.

labels.name: pr-ongoing
labels.description: Pull-request is being worked on to address the labeled ticket.

labels.name: stale
labels.description: Not updated for a longer period of time.

items.body:
The issue reported in #8382.

### Code to reproduce
```python
import chainer
import numpy


for device_spec in ['@numpy', '@cupy:0', 'native:0']:
    print(device_spec)
    device = chainer.backend.get_device(device_spec)

    with chainer.using_config('dtype', numpy.float16):
        model = chainer.Sequential(
            chainer.links.Linear(4, 3),
            chainer.functions.sum,
        )

    model.cleargrads()
    model.to_device(device)
    opt = chainer.optimizers.SGD()
    opt.use_fp32_update()
    opt.setup(model)

    x = numpy.random.randn(2, 4).astype(numpy.float16)
    x = device.send(x)
    y = model(x)
    y.backward()
    opt.update()
    print('ok')
```

### Error messages, stack traces, or logs
```

ok

ok

items.title: Issue management after v7.0.0 release

labels.name: stale
labels.description: Not updated for a longer period of time.

items.body:
As we [announced](https://chainer.org/announcement/2019/12/05/released-v7.html), Chainer will go on to the maintenance phase.

- [ ] Update docs to announce it: README, contribution guide, pull-request template
- [x] Remove `contribution-wanted` label from issues (done: 2019/12/17)
- [x] Reprioritize existing issues

items.title: A problem about update method of Chainermn's multi-node optimizer

labels.name: ChainerMN
labels.description: Related to ChainerMN.

labels.name: stale
labels.description: Not updated for a longer period of time.

items.body:
Sorry, I hava a problem using the multi-node optimizer of chainermn.

The setting of my environment is below:
- Version: 6.2.0
- OS/Platform: Ubuntu 18.04
- Dataset: Cifar-10
- Network Model: VGG16
- GPU: one server with 4 Tesla V100

I was using the [_MultiNodeOptimizer](https://github.com/chainer/chainer/blob/a3c428a32905052e33fc6427f5bfd8ae4b782f79/chainermn/optimizers.py#L5) of Chainermn to train my model.
And I was measuring the time for the [update](https://github.com/chainer/chainer/blob/a3c428a32905052e33fc6427f5bfd8ae4b782f79/chainermn/optimizers.py#L17) method of this multi-node optimizer. 
I broke the time to three parts:
1. Time for forward and backword propagation, which consists of the lines from [calculating of loss](https://github.com/chainer/chainer/blob/a3c428a32905052e33fc6427f5bfd8ae4b782f79/chainermn/optimizers.py#L21) to [backward](https://github.com/chainer/chainer/blob/a3c428a32905052e33fc6427f5bfd8ae4b782f79/chainermn/optimizers.py#L26).
2. Time for networking (allreduce). It is mostly the [allreduce_grad](https://github.com/chainer/chainer/blob/a3c428a32905052e33fc6427f5bfd8ae4b782f79/chainermn/optimizers.py#L32) performed by the MPI communicator.
3. Time for updateing the parameters of model. This is performed by the [updte method](https://github.com/chainer/chainer/blob/a3c428a32905052e33fc6427f5bfd8ae4b782f79/chainermn/optimizers.py#L33) of the actual optimizer.

Then I tried to change the batch size from 128/iter to 512/iter.
I thought that the networking time would **remain the same** even with bigger batch size.( Since we only need to allreduce the gradient of model, right? So It was supposed that the networking time has noting to do with the batch size)
And propagation and update time will **increase** since the model has to process more images in one iteration.

But it turned out that what I thougt was totally wrong.
Below is the result that I got ( I used `time.perf_counter` method to measure the time ):
- batch size: 128 -> 512
- forward/backward propagation: 0.017s -> 0.010s
- network(allreduce) time: **0.035s -> 0.167s**
- update time: 0.0056s -> 0.0034s

Not only the networking time increased, the learning time of model also decreased surprisingly.

So, it would be greatly appreciated that if any one can tell me the cause.
Was my assumption wrong?
Or Chainer was not implemented like I thought?

Thank you very much.

P.S.: I can read Japanese, so it's ok to reply in Japanese. よろしくお願いいたします。

labels.name: stale
labels.description: Not updated for a longer period of time.

items.body:
The link_hooks.SpectralNormalization has a bug the same to #8441.
This is because the link does not have a ``"u-vector"`` if the link has been lazily initialized.
Perhaps it can be fixed in a similar way to #8445.

```

items.title: Feature Request: Add Mish Activation

labels.name: stale
labels.description: Not updated for a longer period of time.

items.body:
Mish is a new novel activation function proposed in this [paper](https://arxiv.org/abs/1908.08681).
It has shown promising results so far and has been adopted in several packages including:

- [TensorFlow-Addons](https://github.com/tensorflow/addons/tree/master/tensorflow_addons/activations)
- [SpaCy (Tok2Vec Layer)](https://github.com/explosion/spaCy)
- [Thinc - SpaCy's official NLP based ML library](https://github.com/explosion/thinc/releases/tag/v7.3.0)
- [Echo AI](https://github.com/digantamisra98/Echo)
- [CNTKX - Extension of Microsoft's CNTK](https://github.com/delzac/cntkx)
- [FastAI-Dev](https://github.com/fastai/fastai_dev/blob/0f613ba3205990c83de9dba0c8798a9eec5452ce/dev/local/layers.py#L441)
- [Darknet](https://github.com/AlexeyAB/darknet/commit/bf8ea4183dc265ac17f7c9d939dc815269f0a213)
- [Yolov3](https://github.com/ultralytics/yolov3/commit/444a9f7099d4ff1aef12783704e3df9a8c3aa4b3)
- [BeeDNN - Library in C++](https://github.com/edeforas/BeeDNN)
- [Gen-EfficientNet-PyTorch](https://github.com/rwightman/gen-efficientnet-pytorch)
- [dnet](https://github.com/umangjpatel/dnet/blob/master/nn/activations.py)

All benchmarks, analysis and links to official package implementations can be found in this [repository](https://github.com/digantamisra98/Mish) 

It would be nice to have Mish as an option within the activation function group.

This is the comparison of Mish with other conventional activation functions in a SEResNet-50 for CIFAR-10: 
![se50_1](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/34192716/69002745-0de37980-091b-11ea-87da-ac8d17c79e07.png)

items.title: Serialization of BatchNormalization statistics fails when layer is initialized using batch axis

labels.name: cat:bug
labels.description: Bug report or fix.

labels.name: pr-ongoing
labels.description: Pull-request is being worked on to address the labeled ticket.

items.body:
BatchNormalization serialization fails to load the stored statistics `avg_mean` and `avg_var` when the layer is initialized using the `axis` parameter rather than `size` parameter. As a result, at test time the BatchNorm layer uses default initialization of 0 and 1 for mean and variance rather than the saved statistics. This is because the `avg_mean` and `avg_var` attributes are initialized and registered as persistent in the `_initialize_params()` method ([link](https://github.com/chainer/chainer/blob/master/chainer/links/normalization/batch_normalization.py#L238)) which is only called on the first forward pass, since the feature dimensions must be inferred from the data. As a result they are skipped by the serializer when loading parameters into a new test-time model prior to passing any data through the model.

To be fixed, the `avg_mean` and `avg_var` attributes would need to be registered as persistent in the BatchNormalization `__init__()` method. In addition, in the loop over persistent attributes in chainer.Link located [here](https://github.com/chainer/chainer/blob/master/chainer/link.py#L663), there would need to be a case handling unitialized persistent attributes that can read the dimension from the serializer in a similar manner to how it is done for parameters.

Here is an example script that demonstrates the problem:
```
import chainer
import numpy as np
from chainer.links import BatchNormalization
from chainer.serializers import load_npz, save_npz

batch_sample = np.random.rand(5, 4, 3, 2).astype(np.float32)

norm_1 = BatchNormalization(axis=(0, 1))

print('norm_1 pre-call persistent values:', norm_1._persistent)
print('norm_1 avg_mean:')
print(norm_1.avg_mean)

norm_1(batch_sample)

print('norm_1 post-call persistent values:', norm_1._persistent)
print('norm_1 avg_mean:')
print(norm_1.avg_mean)
print('')

save_npz('norm.npz', norm_1)

npz = np.load('norm.npz')

print('norm.npz files:', npz.files)
print('norm.npz avg_mean:')
print(npz['avg_mean'])
print('')

chainer.config.train = False

norm_2 = BatchNormalization(axis=(0, 1))
load_npz('norm.npz', norm_2)

print('norm_2 pre-call persistent values:', norm_2._persistent)
print('norm_2 avg_mean:')
print(norm_2.avg_mean)

norm_2(batch_sample)

print('norm_2 post-call persistent values:', norm_2._persistent)
print('norm_2 avg_mean:')
print(norm_2.avg_mean)
```
along with its output:
```
norm_1 pre-call persistent values: {'N'}
norm_1 avg_mean:
None
norm_1 post-call persistent values: {'N', 'avg_mean', 'avg_var'}
norm_1 avg_mean:
[[0.04254831 0.0445514 ]
 [0.04263044 0.04522393]
 [0.05117331 0.05540558]]

norm.npz files: ['gamma', 'beta', 'N', 'avg_mean', 'avg_var']
norm.npz avg_mean:
[[0.04254831 0.0445514 ]
 [0.04263044 0.04522393]
 [0.05117331 0.05540558]]

norm_2 pre-call persistent values: {'N'}
norm_2 avg_mean:
None
norm_2 post-call persistent values: {'N', 'avg_mean', 'avg_var'}
norm_2 avg_mean:
[[0. 0.]
 [0. 0.]
 [0. 0.]]
```
We can see that the avg_mean attribute only exists after a call, and thus even though it is correctly present in the npz archive, those attributes only get created after the parameters have been loaded and use the default initialization values of 0.

And finally, in case it matters, here's the output of print_runtime_info().
```
>>> chainer.print_runtime_info()
Platform: Linux-4.4.0-72-generic-x86_64-with-debian-stretch-sid
Chainer: 6.5.0
ChainerX: Not Available
NumPy: 1.17.1
CuPy:
  CuPy Version          : 6.5.0
  CUDA Root             : /cm/shared/apps/cuda10.0/toolkit/10.0.130
  CUDA Build Version    : 10000
  CUDA Driver Version   : 10010
  CUDA Runtime Version  : 10000
  cuDNN Build Version   : 7603
  cuDNN Version         : 7603
  NCCL Build Version    : 2402
  NCCL Runtime Version  : 2402
iDeep: Not Available
```

labels.name: ONNX
labels.description: Related to ONNX

items.body: Currently, ONNX-Chainer doesn't support Rollaxis. I see that [`chainer.functions.rollaxis`](https://docs.chainer.org/en/stable/reference/generated/chainer.functions.rollaxis.html) is in Chainer's API only for backward compatibility, but it is better to be supported in ONNX-Chainer.

items.title: Docs build is warned by Sphinx>=2

labels.name: cat:document
labels.description: Documentation such as function documentations, comments and tutorials.

labels.name: prio:high
labels.description: High priority. Urgent and needs to be worked on as soon as possible.

labels.name: stale
labels.description: Not updated for a longer period of time.

items.body:
Sphinx (`2.2.1` or `master`) produces the following two kinds of warnings in my environment.

### `duplicate object description`

I think cross refs to such object is ambiguous.

### `autosummary: stub file not found`

There are

- `chainer.dataset.Converter` base class and
- `chainer.dataset.converter` decorator.

Therefore the filesystem has to allow to store `chainer.dataset.Converter.html` and `chainer.dataset.converter.html` to build the docs.

BTW, the warning message is buggy: `.rst` is repeated in `/path/to/chainer/docs/source/reference/datasets.rst.rst:69: WARNING: autosummary: stub file not found 'chainer.dataset.converter'. Check your autosummary_generate setting.`


## Code to reproduce
```
cd docs
make clean
make html
```
### Error messages, stack traces, or logs
```
/path/to/chainer/docs/source/chainermn/model_parallel/index.rst:1: WARNING: duplicate object description of chainermn, other instance in chainermn/installation/index, use :noindex: for one of them

items.title: Can't pickle optimizer from chainer>=6.2.0

labels.name: cat:bug
labels.description: Bug report or fix.

items.body:
```python
import chainer
import pickle

lnk = chainer.links.Linear(1, 2)
opt = chainer.optimizers.Adam().setup(lnk)
print(pickle.dumps(opt))
```

The above code is fine for chainer<=6.1.0 but raises an error for >=6.2.0.

```python
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "pickle_opt.py", line 6, in <module>
    print(pickle.dumps(opt))
AttributeError: Can't pickle local object 'Optimizer.setup.<locals>.OptimizerHookable'
```

I'm not sure if users can expect optimizers to be pickle-able, but this can be a problem e.g. when passing an optimizer to another process for multiprocessing.

items.title: ChainerX error indexing arrays with more than 2^31 elements

labels.name: ChainerX
labels.description: Related to ChainerX.

labels.name: cat:bug
labels.description: Bug report or fix.

labels.name: pr-ongoing
labels.description: Pull-request is being worked on to address the labeled ticket.

items.body:
When indexing an array with more than 2^31 elements, the cuda backend access the array incorrectly

Test code
```python
import chainerx

# More than 2**32 elems
a=chainerx.zeros(shape=(64,32,6*1024*512), dtype=chainerx.int8, device='cuda:0')
a+=1

print(a.ravel()[0])
print(a.ravel()[-1])


# Less than 2**32 elems
a=chainerx.zeros(shape=(64,32,6*1024*4), dtype=chainerx.int8, device='cuda:0')
a+=1

print(a.ravel()[0])
print(a.ravel()[-1])
```

The first two prints yield 2 and 3, while the last two are correct.

Cause could be some variable overflow on the iterator?

items.body:
It should test `x.ndim`.

* Conditions
```

  NCCL Runtime Version  : (unknown)
iDeep: 2.0.0.post3
```

* Code to reproduce
```python
import chainer
import chainerx
import numpy as np


np.random.seed(0)
x = np.random.randn(8, 9, 2, 3, 4).astype('f')
devices = ['@cupy:0', 'cuda:0']
for axis in [
        (0,),  # fallback
        (0, 2, 3, 4),  # cudnn
        (0, 2, 3),  # bad
]:
    print(axis)
    ys = [
        chainer.get_device('@numpy').send(
            chainer.links.BatchNormalization(axis=axis).to_device(device)(

items.title: ChainerMN tutorial: misleading description about `scatter_dataset`

labels.name: ChainerMN
labels.description: Related to ChainerMN.

items.body:
The tutorial of ChainerMN about `scatter_dataset` says as follows:

* The dataset is split into sub datasets of **almost equal sizes** and scattered to the workers.

https://github.com/chainer/chainer/blob/master/docs/source/chainermn/tutorial/step2_datasets_evaluators.rst#scattering-datasets

I think this description misleading because by default, `scatter_dataset` splits it into sub datasets of exactly the same sizes.

It may be a good idea to replace the description to something like: `exactly the same sizes with some duplications as necessary`.

items.title: chainerx.ascontiguousarray() does not preserve the backend of the array

labels.name: ChainerX
labels.description: Related to ChainerX.

labels.name: cat:bug
labels.description: Bug report or fix.

items.body:
`chainerx.ascontiguousarray()` function is expected to keep the backend of the original array.

```
import chainer
import chainerx as chx

a1 = chx.arange(10)
a2 = a1.to_device('cuda:0')
a3 = chx.ascontiguousarray(a2)
print(a1.device.backend.name)
print(a2.device.backend.name)
print(a3.device.backend.name)
=>
native
cuda
native  # <== expected to be 'cuda'
```

items.body:
When LARS is used, it is expected that LR given to the optimizer is already multiplied by eta.

https://github.com/chainer/chainer/blob/30fcfa67e6e21ff6682bcbda0fdd1543a203cae6/chainer/optimizer_hooks/gradient_lars.py#L101
Therefore, in the code above, if the norm of weight (p_norm) is less than the threshold, the actual LR applied to the parameter is lr * eta, where lr is the one user meant to use.
Is this the expected behavior?

items.title: Apply pairwise parameterization selectively in tests

labels.name: cat:test
labels.description: Test or CI related.

labels.name: prio:low
labels.description: Low priority. Nice-to-have.

labels.name: stale
labels.description: Not updated for a longer period of time.

items.body:
#8164 applied pairwise parameterization in tests unconditionally in `chainer_tests` and `chainerx_tests`, but I think it's too dangerous.  Some tests might be designed carefully in a way that omitting some of their combination would lead to degradation of the tests.
Ideally we should apply pairwise testing only selectively in those tests that are
* taking large amount of time, and
* their parameterization are not easily reduced by hand.

We should also provide a method to switch whether to enable pairwise parameterization, and only enable it in Travis CI (otherwise we don't have timeout issue).

However it would take too much time to check existing tests manually. We have an immediate timeout issue in Travis CI.

So I suggest at first adding a method to switch the mode as mentioned above.
Initially choices would be "always" and "never" (default), and later we would add another mode "selective" (or whatever name) in which mode pairwise parameterization would be applied only in designated tests.

items.title: pytest fails with Python 2

labels.name: stale
labels.description: Not updated for a longer period of time.

items.body:
`pytest` fails with Python 2 because warnings are considered as errors (unless explicitly excluded) by pytest according to `setup.cfg` and current Chainer raises UserWarning if run on Python 2:
```
INTERNALERROR> UserWarning:
INTERNALERROR> --------------------------------------------------------------------------------
INTERNALERROR> Chainer is going to stop supporting Python 2 in v7.x releases.
INTERNALERROR>
INTERNALERROR> Future releases of Chainer v7.x will not run on Python 2.
INTERNALERROR> If you need to continue using Python 2, consider using Chainer v6.x, which
INTERNALERROR> will be the last version that runs on Python 2.
INTERNALERROR> --------------------------------------------------------------------------------
```
I suppose that this kind of `UserWarning` should be explicitly marked as negligible in `setup.cfg`.

items.title: Order of Registration for Sequential Chains
items.body:
It should be noted somewhere that the Sequential Chains and their parameters do not respect the expected order of registration. This causes confusion when returning parameters from the associated generators.

```
class TestChain(Chain):
    def __init__(self):
        super().__init__()
        ndf = 2
        with self.init_scope():
            self.l0 = L.Convolution2D(ndf, ndf, ksize=3, nobias=True)
            self.l1 = L.Convolution2D(ndf, ndf, ksize=3, nobias=True)
            self.l2 = L.Convolution2D(ndf, ndf, ksize=3, nobias=True)
            self.main = Sequential(
                L.Convolution2D(ndf, ndf, nobias=True),
                F.leaky_relu,
                L.Convolution2D(ndf, ndf, nobias=True),
                F.leaky_relu,
                L.Convolution2D(ndf, ndf, nobias=True),
                F.leaky_relu,
                L.Convolution2D(ndf, ndf, nobias=True),
                F.leaky_relu,
                L.BatchNormalization(ndf, use_beta=False),
            )
            self.l3 = L.Convolution2D(ndf, ndf, ksize=3, nobias=True)
            self.l4 = L.Convolution2D(ndf, ndf, ksize=3, nobias=True)
            self.l5 = L.Convolution2D(ndf, ndf, ksize=3, nobias=True)



```
```
t =  TestChain()
for p in t.namedparams():
    print(p[0])
```

https://github.com/chainer/chainer/blob/c4328a95a0db4adb8583f0a1d08ef03beabe2dfe/examples/wavenet/net.py#L49

items.title: ChainerMN `test_create_mnbn_model.py` fails

labels.name: ChainerMN
labels.description: Related to ChainerMN.

labels.name: cat:bug
labels.description: Bug report or fix.

labels.name: prio:high
labels.description: High priority. Urgent and needs to be worked on as soon as possible.

items.body:
**Error**
ChainerMN `test_create_mnbn_model.py` fails with following messages
```
=================================== FAILURES ===================================
_____________ TestCreateMnBnModel.test_create_mnbn_model_chain_gpu _____________

self = <test_create_mnbn_model.TestCreateMnBnModel testMethod=test_create_mnbn_model_chain_gpu>

    @chainer.testing.attr.gpu
    def test_create_mnbn_model_chain_gpu(self):
>       self.check_create_mnbn_model_chain(gpu=True)

chainermn_tests/links_tests/test_create_mnbn_model.py:107:
_ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _
chainermn_tests/links_tests/test_create_mnbn_model.py:56: in check_create_mnbn_model_chain
    mnbn_model(x)
../chainer/link.py:294: in __call__
    out = forward(*args, **kwargs)
chainermn_tests/links_tests/test_create_mnbn_model.py:19: in forward
    return chainer.functions.relu(self.bn(self.conv(x)))
../chainermn/links/batch_normalization.py:111: in __call__
    ret = func.apply((x, gamma, beta))[0]
../chainer/function_node.py:325: in apply
    outputs = self.forward(in_data)
../chainer/functions/normalization/batch_normalization.py:401: in forward
    running_var=self.running_var)
../chainer/functions/normalization/batch_normalization.py:80: in forward
    running_mean, running_var)
cupy/core/_kernel.pyx:539: in cupy.core._kernel.ElementwiseKernel.__call__
    ???
cupy/core/_kernel.pyx:582: in cupy.core._kernel.ElementwiseKernel._decide_params_type
    ???
_ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _

>   ???
E   TypeError: Type is mismatched. mean <class 'numpy.float64'> <class 'numpy.float32'> U

cupy/core/_kernel.pyx:292: TypeError
====================== 1 failed, 1 passed in 3.63 seconds ======================
```


**Main Cause**
`mean` and `var` have a different dtype `<numpy.float64>` from others `<numpy.float32> `, which violate the assumption that all the variables share the same dtype at https://github.com/chainer/chainer/blob/23f1fdbe7c534dc48538eaaff660c376a151049e/chainer/functions/normalization/batch_normalization.py#L66

The cupy elementwise code was from old chainermn implementation, and chainermn got the dtype of `mean` and `var` only from `gamma` https://github.com/chainer/chainer/blob/b02a7c402bef7f912c2d7109f07bda9438c3d57f/chainermn/functions/batch_normalization.py#L39, which makes all the dtype the same.
While chainer has changed to promote the dtype of `gamma` with `x` (<numpy.float64>) ,https://github.com/chainer/chainer/blob/b02a7c402bef7f912c2d7109f07bda9438c3d57f/chainer/functions/normalization/batch_normalization.py#L222, which makes them `float64`, and causes this bug.

items.title: `finetune`, the argument of BatchNormalization's `forward` is forgotten

labels.name: prio:medium
labels.description: Medium priority. Should be worked on but does not require immediate action.

labels.name: stale
labels.description: Not updated for a longer period of time.

items.body:
Currently, when users want to do finetune for BN, they have to implement their model to be able to change `finetune` the parameter of BN's `forward` function. It is just so hard (and no one seems to do so). `finetune` is usefull and may increase model's accuracy without any cost tho.
`finetune` should be changable as well as configurations e.g. `train`. 
https://github.com/chainer/chainer/blob/master/chainer/links/normalization/batch_normalization.py#L286

items.title: Non-pure-reduction routines in ChainerX to be excluded

labels.name: ChainerX
labels.description: Related to ChainerX.

items.body:
The intent of this issue is to clarify or discuss the motivation behind keeping a minimal set of backpropable routines in ChainerX for the sake of simplicity.

Non-pure-reduction routines*, although common in the field of DL, such as _mean squared error_, might better be excluded from ChainerX as long as the non-reduction variant, in this case _squared error_ is provided. Please see this [comment](https://github.com/chainer/chainer/pull/7063#issuecomment-496087996). To elaborate, basically any routine in ChainerX might be a candidate for any reduction (not just mean, but max, min, etc.). As pure-reduction routines such as _mean, max, min_, etc. are provided in ChainerX, this is possible without any dedicated non-pure-reduction routines.

Also note that when performing a reduction, it should be possible to specify over which axes the reduction should take place. This further complicates interfaces.

*_Pure-reduction routines: Routines that by definition perform reduction. Non-pure-reduction routines: Routines that are well defined without reduction._

labels.name: prio:high
labels.description: High priority. Urgent and needs to be worked on as soon as possible.

items.body:
```py
> import chainer
> import chainer.links as L
```

CPU batchsize 64

```py
>> c =  L.ConvolutionND(3, 3, 64, ksize=3, stride=1, pad=1)
>> d = c.xp.random.randn(64,3,16,64,64).astype('f')
>> c(d).array.var()
0.9107105
>> c(d).array.mean()
-4.8422127e-05
```

Move to GPU

```py
>> c.to_gpu()

<chainer.links.connection.convolution_nd.ConvolutionND object at 0x7f99c0408990>

>> d = c.xp.random.randn(64,3,16,64,64).astype('f')
>> c(d).array.mean()
array(-0.00012456, dtype=float32)
>> c(d).array.var()
array(0.9110826, dtype=float32)
```

GPU batchsize = 32

```py
>> d = c.xp.random.randn(32,3,16,64,64).astype('f')
>> c(d).array.mean()
array(0., dtype=float32)
>> c(d).array.var()
array(0., dtype=float32)
```

GPU batchsize = 64

```py
>> d = c.xp.random.randn(64,3,16,64,64).astype('f')

array(-3.2548433e-06, dtype=float32)

GPU batchsize = 32

```py

>> c(d).array.mean()
array(0., dtype=float32)
>> c(d).array.var()
array(0., dtype=float32)

**array(True)**

items.title: Possibly inappropriate use of `OptionalAxes` and `Axes` to represent one-sized axes

labels.name: ChainerX
labels.description: Related to ChainerX.

labels.name: cat:enhancement
labels.description: Implementation that does not break interfaces.

labels.name: prio:low
labels.description: Low priority. Nice-to-have.

labels.name: stale
labels.description: Not updated for a longer period of time.

items.body:
ChainerX routines that accept a single optional integer as an axis (not a tuple) currently accepts `absl::optional<int8_t>`. Although this is fine, its cast to an `OptionalAxes` (container type) before being passed to the C++ routine. The C++ routine may thus accept multiple axes but lengths larger than 1 are not tested since there are no tests in C++. 

E.g. `chainerx.argmax` only takes a single integer for its axis and not a tuple of integers. However, the kernel takes a tuple. https://github.com/chainer/chainer/blob/master/chainerx_cc/chainerx/native/native_device/reduction.cc#L36.

items.title: Default value for non-differentiable point detection to be reconsidered

labels.name: cat:feature
labels.description: Implementation that introduces new interfaces.

labels.name: prio:medium
labels.description: Medium priority. Should be worked on but does not require immediate action.

labels.name: stale
labels.description: Not updated for a longer period of time.

items.body:
Non-differentiable point detection in the gradient check relies on tolerances. The absolute tolerance is fixed to 0 and the relative tolerances is the relative tolerance configured for the numerical gradient check https://github.com/chainer/chainer/blob/master/chainer/gradient_check.py#L743. 

Maybe those should be configurable in a more flexible manner, e.g. a separate argument to the gradient check. We might want to reconsider the default value as well.

items.title: A non-ChainerMN data parallel ImageNet example doesn't work well in a container including NVIDIA DALI.

labels.name: contribution-welcome
labels.description: Contribution is welcomed. If a ticket has this label, anyone is welcomed to work on it.

items.body:
Hello, team!

I encountered a trivial issue that the ImageNet data parallel example (non-ChainerMN example; https://github.com/chainer/chainer/blob/v6.3.0/examples/imagenet/train_imagenet_data_parallel.py ) stops soon when the script runs in the environment where NVIDIA DALI is installed. According to the stack trace, the conflict of CUDA context initialization seems to cause this issue.

Conditions are below. I guess the number of affected users by this issue is very limited so it's not a critical problem. Please fix it if you team have enough time. (Or, I can make a PR. Please feel free to let me know if I should do so.)

* Conditions
  - Chainer version: chainer (6.3.0)
  - CuPy version: cupy-cuda100 (6.3.0)
  - OS/Platform: Ubuntu 18.04.2 LTS
  - CUDA/cuDNN version: 10.0.130 / 7.6.0
  - Python: 3.6.8
  - A container used in my test is built by this Dockerfile ( https://gist.github.com/lazykyama/92b235b8fe0f71ed7d000c9cbfee5732 ).
* Code to reproduce
  - `cd examples/imagenet/`
  - `python3 train_imagenet_data_parallel.py --arch resnet50 --devices @cupy:0 @cupy:1 --root / /path/to/imagenet/train_pair.txt /path/to/imagenet/val_pair.txt`
* Error messages, stack traces, or logs
  - Stack trace was shown like below.

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "train_imagenet_data_parallel.py", line 149, in <module>
    main()
  File "train_imagenet_data_parallel.py", line 116, in main
    devices=devices)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.6/dist-packages/chainer/training/updaters/multiprocess_parallel_updater.py", line 138, in __init__
    'The CUDA context has been already initialized. '
RuntimeError: The CUDA context has been already initialized. MultiprocessParallelUpdater assumes the context is uninitialized. Please do not call CUDA API before MultiprocessParallelUpdater creates processes.
```

Workaround: making the timing to import DALI delayed like below.

```diff
diff --git a/examples/imagenet/train_imagenet.py b/examples/imagenet/train_imagenet.py
index bed9014fb..1557ea8c8 100755
--- a/examples/imagenet/train_imagenet.py
+++ b/examples/imagenet/train_imagenet.py
@@ -19,8 +19,6 @@ from chainer import training
 from chainer.training import extensions
 import chainerx

-import dali_util
-
 import alex
 import googlenet
 import googlenetbn
@@ -150,6 +148,8 @@ def main():
     # Load the mean file
     mean = np.load(args.mean)
     if args.dali:
+        import dali_util
+
         if not dali_util._dali_available:
             raise RuntimeError('DALI seems not available on your system.')
         if not isinstance(device, chainer.backend.cuda.GpuDevice):
```
